The private beach access is a big plus, giving it a relaxed and exclusive feel. Food service was decent, though slightly on the expensive side.

Overall, everything was good, and I’d definitely recommend it for a calm and enjoyable getaway.

Foods are good in taste and adequate quantity and quality.

It is quiet and perfect for relaxing. You must watch the sunrise from here, it’s really beautiful. I would definitely recommend this resort for a peaceful and pleasant stay.

From the moment I arrived, the staff were rude and unprofessional, completely disregarding basic customer service. The swimming pool and restrooms were filthy, clearly lacking regular cleaning or maintenance. Hygiene was completely ignored, which is unacceptable for a resort that charges guests a premium. The lack of cleanliness made it uncomfortable to use the facilities.

To make matters worse, the food quality was extremely poor. The meals served were stale and lacked proper hygiene standards, making it impossible to enjoy dining at the resort. For the price paid, the food was a complete disappointment.

Overall, this resort is poorly managed and does not prioritize guest satisfaction. I strongly do not recommend this place to anyone looking for a relaxing and enjoyable stay. Spend your money elsewhere where you will be treated with respect and offered a clean and comfortable environment.

placeMetadata.description: World Heritage-listed, shoreline, stone temple complex dating from the 7th–8th centuries.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Group of Monuments at Mahabalipuram, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is a collection of ancient stone temples and structures dating back to the 7th–8th centuries. Located on the Coramandel Coast in Tamil Nadu, India, this site features impressive Rathas (chariots), cave sanctuaries, and open-air reliefs such as the famous Arjuna Penance.
placeMetadata.address: Fisherman Colony, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

reviews.reviewText:
Mahabalipuram Shore Temple:
* The Shore Temple is praised for its impressive architecture and design, featuring intricate stone carvings and pyramidal towers.
* Its location near the beach offers a beautiful view and enhances the ambiance.
* The temple is generally well-maintained and clean, with available amenities.
* Many reviewers suggest hiring a guide to fully appreciate the historical significance.
* Some visitors advise against visiting during the hot summer months.
* The temple is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a masterpiece of Pallava art.
Group of Monuments at Mahabalipuram:
* The site showcases the finest examples of ancient Pallava architecture and sculpture.
* Key features include the Five Rathas (monolithic rock-cut temples), Arjuna's Penance (rock-cut caves with intricate sculptures), and Krishna's Butter Ball (a massive, precariously balanced boulder).
* The monuments are recognized by UNESCO for their outstanding universal value and cultural significance.
* The site offers a glimpse into India's rich cultural heritage and the artistic and engineering marvels of the Pallava dynasty.
Would you like to know more about any specific aspect of these temples or any other place in Mahabalipuram?

Tickets are required for entry. And easily it can be bought on counter. The place is very very pretty.
The sunset time and once the lights are on the temple looks even more prettier.
Not much rush found and really good place to enjoy historical view with beach around.

Well maintained and impressive monuments. Worth getting a guide to understand the history, architectural styles and construction methods. Some of the sea facing facades are eroding but the none sea facing ones are still in good condition with a small amount of the original color remaining.

Big temple ruins on sea shore of Mahabalipuram. Showing 5 ratha of Pandavas. 1 for each . For Nakul and Sahdev 1 combined ratha, and 1 for Draupadi. Beautifully carved. Must see if u interested in history.

Ancient temples that reflect the glory of erstwhile kingdoms, pristine beaches that emanate matchless natural beauty, rich cultural heritage that welcomes you
Mamallapuram (Mahabalipuram) is known for its 6th-century masterpieces of Pallava architecture. I recommend that anyone interested visit in the early morning to avoid the sun and crowds. Sunday there is lot of rush.

Hey I recently visited the iconic Shore Temple in Mahabalipuram, and it was truly a mesmerizing experience. Standing proudly on the shores of the Bay of Bengal, this 8th-century marvel is one of the oldest stone temples in South India and a testament to the rich architectural heritage of the Pallava dynasty.

The temple’s stunning location – right by the sea – adds a mystical charm. As the waves crash in the background, the sound blends beautifully with the serene vibe of the site. The carvings on the granite stones are incredibly detailed, showcasing stories from Hindu mythology and the craftsmanship of ancient artisans.

The entire complex is well-maintained, and the early morning or sunset views are breathtaking. It’s not just a visit to a historical monument; it feels like a spiritual and cultural journey. Ideal for history buffs, architecture lovers, photographers, and peace seekers alike.

✅ Tips:
•	Visit early morning or during sunset for the best lighting and weather.
•	Wear comfortable shoes – it’s a walking site.
•	Don’t forget to explore the nearby Five Rathas and Arjuna’s Penance.

"Mahabalipuram is a living museum of Pallava art and architecture. The stone carvings tell epics from Mahabharata and Ramayana, and it’s fascinating how such precision was achieved centuries ago. Standing before the Shore Temple, you feel the timelessness of India’s heritage. A must-visit for anyone who loves history and culture. This place is a photographer’s dream! The carvings at Pancha Rathas and Arjuna’s Penance are jaw-dropping, especially in golden hour light. The Shore Temple against the backdrop of waves feels straight out of a postcard. Every corner has a story, and every frame is Insta-worthy.

Mahabalipuram is a stunning UNESCO World Heritage site, rich with ancient rock-cut architecture, temples, and sculptures dating back to the Pallava dynasty (7th–8th century). A must-visit for history lovers, photographers, and travelers seeking a cultural experience.

Highlights include:
🪨 Shore Temple – Beautiful seaside stone temple, especially magical at sunrise/sunset.
🐘 Arjuna's Penance – A massive rock relief filled with intricate carvings and divine figures.
🛕 Pancha Rathas – Monolithic chariots carved from single rocks, each unique in style.
🪙 Krishna’s Butter Ball – A giant boulder seemingly defying gravity!

The entire site is walkable, well-maintained, and has informative signboards. Guides are available for deeper insights.

Best visited early morning or late afternoon to avoid heat. Entry ticket is affordable (~₹40 for Indians), and the vibe is peaceful and spiritual.

Perfect mix of history, architecture, and coastal charm. Highly recommended!

Arjuna’s Penance is a massive open-air rock relief in Mahabalipuram, carved in the 7th century.
It depicts scenes from Hindu mythology, including Arjuna’s penance to please Lord Shiva.
The intricate carvings feature gods, sages, animals, and river scenes in amazing detail.
It’s one of India’s finest ancient stone carvings, standing 43 feet high and 96 feet long.
A must-see spot in Mahabalipuram, especially in the early morning or evening light.

The Descent of the Ganga River and Arjuna’s Penance is truly a masterpiece of ancient Indian rock cut art. The huge bas-relief carved on the massive rock surface is breathtaking, with intricate details that depict mythological stories, gods, sages, animals, and everyday life. Standing in front of it makes you appreciate the scale, creativity, and skill of the Pallava artisans.

The place is well maintained, though it can get crowded with tourists, especially during weekends. A guide really helps in understanding the deeper meaning of the carvings and the historical significance. The surroundings are clean, and it’s located near other important monuments in Mahabalipuram, making it easy to cover as part of the heritage walk.

A must-visit if you are in Mahabalipuram it’s like reading a story carved in stone.

Mahabalipuram's magnificent stone architecture beautifully reflects India's rich history. The sheer size and scale of the structures are so vast that capturing them in a single image is nearly impossible. Visitors from around the world come to admire the intricate carvings and experience the essence of ancient Indian history. Since all the major attractions are best explored on foot, carrying a water bottle is advisable, especially on hot days. It's a wonderful place to spend a peaceful evening with family, soaking in the beauty of history and nature.

Arjuna’s Penance, also known as Descent of the Ganges, is one of the most breathtaking and intricate rock carvings I’ve ever seen. The sheer size and detail of the bas-relief are awe-inspiring. You can easily spend 30–45 minutes just admiring the stories etched into the rock — from gods and animals to sages and celestial beings.

The location is clean, walkable, and filled with other beautiful monuments nearby like the Krishna Butter Ball and the Shore Temple. It’s best to visit early morning or late afternoon to avoid the heat and crowds.

Great for history lovers, photographers, and anyone who wants to experience India’s ancient art and architecture up close. Highly recommend stopping here if you’re in or around Mahabalipuram!

Arjuna’s Penance, also known as the Descent of the Ganges, is truly one of the most breathtaking and intricate rock carvings I’ve ever seen. This massive open-air rock relief, carved in the 7th century at Mahabalipuram, is a masterpiece of stone architecture that beautifully reflects India’s rich history and heritage

This massive rock relief in Mahabalipuram is one of India’s finest ancient carvings. reviews.reviewText:
📍Varah Cave is in Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu, about 60 km from Chennai and within the UNESCO World Heritage Site complex. It’s near the Shore Temple area, making it easy to find and explore.

Significance
This 7th-century rock-cut cave, dedicated to Lord Vishnu's Varaha (boar) incarnation, is an example of early Pallava architecture. Its carvings depict Varaha lifting the Earth, a symbol of divine protection.

Highlights
The cave’s intricate carvings and detailed sculptures showcase ancient legends with expressive figures and fluid lines, making it a captivating stop for history and art enthusiasts.

Very beautiful sculpture of Varahanaraminha!

This is honestly a wonder! It's beyond my imagination how this can exist. It's in the same place as other monuments, you can pay 40 rs for entry at the cash counter and 35 if you book online with the help of QR code.

Wonderful! The huge carvings on the walls of the caves are mesmerizing!
Located near Royagopuram and Ganesha cave.
Worth visiting.

Varaha Cave Temple is a 7th-century rock-cut shrine in Mahabalipuram built by the Pallavas.
It’s famous for the beautiful carving of Lord Vishnu’s Varaha avatar rescuing Goddess Earth.
A peaceful, well-preserved spot showcasing early Dravidian stone art and mythology.

This ancient temple, intricately carved out of solid rock, showcases the incredible skill and artistry of the Pallava dynasty.
&The detailed carvings and sculptures, particularly the depiction of Lord Vishnu as Varaha (the boar), are mesmerizing and offer a glimpse into India's rich cultural heritage.
*The temple's serene ambiance and historical significance make it a must-visit site for history enthusiasts and tourists alike. Standing in front of this masterpiece, you can't help but marvel at the craftsmanship and dedication that went into its creation. Highly recommend visiting this awe-inspiring temple!

The Varaha Cave Temple is a small but impressive rock-cut cave located within the main heritage zone of Mahabalipuram. It’s one of the lesser-crowded monuments, which makes it a calm and quiet place to explore.

The main highlight is the sculpture of Lord Vishnu in the Varaha (boar) avatar, rescuing Bhudevi. The carvings are detailed and showcase the skill of Pallava artisans. The site also includes other mythological reliefs like Trivikrama and Gajalakshmi.

While the site itself is not very large and can be explored in 10–15 minutes, it’s worth a stop if you’re visiting nearby attractions like Arjuna’s Penance or the Mahishasuramardini Cave. It gives a good glimpse into early South Indian rock-cut architecture.

These caves are in opposite directions off seashore temple around 1 km. It's all about the art and craft of that era which is amazing and Mistry for today. Caves have sculptures and temples in it. It gives you Positive Vibes and make you think how they did it. So many of that available.

Perfect for history lovers and photographers seeking to capture timeless artistry

placeMetadata.name: India Seashell Museum

sources.shortName: Mahabalipuram Beach, Chennai | Ticket Price | Timings

placeMetadata.description: Collection of approximately 40,000 seashells & marine fossils from around the world.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The India Seashell Museum, located near the Pancha Rathas Monument in Mahabalipuram, is a unique and educational attraction showcasing approximately 40,000 seashells and marine fossils from around the world. This newly built museum offers a varied display of snails, oysters, and other shell varieties. It is also home to Asia's largest sea shell collection and features a shopping center called Maya bazaar where visitors can find elegant jewelry and artifacts made from seashells.
placeMetadata.address: 191/1A2, opposite Five Rathas Street, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

reviews.reviewText:
We recently visited the India Seashell Museum as a family of three—my wife, our 1-year-old daughter, and myself—and we were genuinely amazed by the experience. Nestled in Mahabalipuram, this museum is a true treasure trove for anyone curious about the ocean and its wonders.

From the moment we stepped inside, we were impressed by the sheer variety and detail in the seashell collection. It’s hard to believe such an extensive and beautifully curated museum exists in India! There are thousands of shells on display—from the tiniest micro-shells to large, rare, and intricately shaped marine specimens. Each section is thoughtfully laid out, with clear information and a lot of interesting facts, making the visit not just enjoyable but also educational.

Our little daughter had a great time too! She was full of curiosity, crawling around happily and enjoying the colorful displays and the calm indoor atmosphere. The museum is clean, well-organized, and safe for families with small children.

They also have additional attractions like a small aquarium and a gift shop, where you can buy unique shell-based souvenirs. The staff were polite and helpful, and the entire place had a peaceful vibe that added to the charm of the visit.

Overall, the India Seashell Museum is a wonderful destination for families, nature lovers, and anyone interested in marine life. It’s informative, peaceful, and quite unique—definitely worth including in your Mahabalipuram itinerary.

Had a good collection of specimens of shells, minerals, starfish, pearls,  different live fishes. Would be good to take kids, especially with some pre-visit intro on marine life, pearls, shells. The dinosaurs museum was good as well. Went for the combo package that covers everything in the premises. Could be priced a bit lower. Adequate car parking space was available.

It's very nice place to explore and see different kind of shells collected from different countries

Here dinosaurs park is awesome and kids will enjoy like anything.

Pricing is little high .

It's best to explore in the mid  of the day when you explore other parts of mahabalipuram.

You can spend two hours here .

As this place is mostly covered by Air conditioners, you can spend in the mid of the day . Other places can be explored in evening and morning time.

Food is costly here.

You can explore outside for food

Nice place to visit with family. There are 7 museums inside. Kids will enjoy the dinosaur museum. Dinosaur, Art and fishing museums are the interesting ones. There is a gaming zone, cafe and a pearl shop as well. Have sufficient parking .

It is a short but unique experience to see different kinds of seashells from all around the world in one place. They're all unique and beautiful in their own ways. However, the seashell collection tour ends pretty quickly and then there are adjacent attractions like the pearl museum and Jurassic park. Still it is an experience i think you should do atleast once.

Worth watching once and definitely needs interest to view and explore the museum. Combo offer costs Rs.400/- for all and for kids below 5 years it’s free and it’s bit costly can be around 300 only. Cafeteria is very costly and the Mojito and the tea weren’t prepared well. They have enough car parking. The 3D art gallery is total waste of money.

The India Seashell Museum in Mahabalipuram is a privately maintained attraction showcasing an impressive personal collection of seashells. It stands out as one of the largest seashell museums in Asia, offering a unique experience for visitors interested in marine life and natural history. The museum complex also includes additional attractions like a Pearl Museum, Fishing Museum, and even a Dinosaur Park, making it a multi-theme destination suitable for families and children.

Each section of the complex has a separate entry fee, though a combined entry ticket is available for approximately ₹800. While the pricing may feel a bit steep, the air-conditioned interiors and the shade make it a great mid-day stop, especially when the sun is at its peak. Planning your day to visit other Mahabalipuram landmarks in the morning or evening and this museum during the hotter hours is a smart move.

The exhibits are well-curated, and a visit of 1–2 hours is generally enough to explore the entire complex. Although the entry fee might seem expensive to some, the variety and uniqueness of the exhibits make it worth a visit for those interested in natural curiosities and marine collections.
Visual treat to the visitors with mind blowing display of Sea shells of various sizes. Turkish fish pedicure is refreshing. Maya bazar is great place to buy some pearls, Sea Shells and gifts

sources.snippet: Krishna’s butterball is a perfect example of what defying gravity is!. It is a huge boulder just resting on the tip of a rock. It does look like the boulder will come rolling down any moment!
sources.shortName: Heritage city of the mighty Pallavas, temples & beaches

placeMetadata.description: Offbeat tourist attraction featuring a massive granite boulder perched on a downhill slope.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Krishna's Butter Ball is a unique and offbeat tourist attraction located in Mahabalipuram. It features a massive granite boulder, measuring six meters in height and five meters in width, with an estimated weight of 250 tons. The boulder is perched on a downhill slope in a truly mystical and mysterious manner, defying all laws of physics and reason.
placeMetadata.address: E Raja St, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

reviews.reviewText: Visiting Krishna's Butter Ball in Chennai was like stepping into a storybook from my childhood 🪨✨. I remember walking up the rocky path under the warm sun, and the moment I saw that giant boulder perfectly balanced on a slope, I was speechless — how could something so big just stand there, untouched for centuries? 😮🙏 I sat beneath it with my cousins, half nervous it might roll, half amazed by its calm presence. We laughed, clicked funny pictures pretending to hold it up, and shared stories under its shadow 📸😂. It wasn’t just a tourist spot — it felt like a moment of connection with nature, history, and my loved ones. A simple rock, but a memory that will stay in my heart forever 💖🌞.

Looks like a marvel.
A boulder balanced by gravity.
In addition there are multiple temples and view points.
There's landscape garden to relax and rest. People do come with food for picnic.
Many aesthetic points to click pictures

We had good times there yesterday. It’s a beautiful rock balanced by gravity. It is intact for decades now and still holds up well. It’s a beautiful place and maintained by Archeological department of India. There is an entry fee of R/s.40 per adult and there are no designated parking lots but the place is beautiful and breathtaking. Must visit place.

Unforgettable Trip to Krishna's Butterball, Mahabalipuram

Last October, I had the joy of visiting Krishna’s Butterball in Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu, with my parents, and it was truly one of the best trips we've ever had. This unique and mysterious giant rock, balanced on a slope, left us all amazed and full of wonder.

The atmosphere was vibrant and filled with the laughter of tourists, children running around, and families capturing memories. We were fascinated by how this massive boulder, weighing over 250 tons, has remained unmoved for centuries — almost defying gravity! Standing beside it, we couldn’t stop admiring nature’s miracle and the historical charm surrounding it.

Exploring the area was both fun and relaxing. We climbed nearby rocks, took dozens of photos, and enjoyed the scenic views all around. The weather was pleasant, and the cool breeze made the entire experience even more refreshing. My parents, too, were thrilled and kept talking about the uniqueness of the place.

One of the highlights was simply sitting on the grass, enjoying some local snacks, and soaking in the peaceful surroundings. The trip wasn’t just about sightseeing, but also about bonding, laughter, and quality time together.

Krishna’s Butterball, with its playful name and incredible presence, gave us memories that we will always treasure. Visiting this spot made us feel connected to both nature and history. I would highly recommend this place to anyone looking for a light-hearted yet awe-inspiring travel experience with family.

"Krishna’s Butter Ball is truly a wonder of nature and history combined. The gigantic boulder perched so delicately on a slope looks almost impossible, yet it has stood there for centuries without moving an inch. The spot is peaceful yet lively, with families enjoying picnics and children rolling down the grassy hill. It’s not just a monument but an experience—you feel the magic of balance and the mystery of time. A must-visit landmark in Mahabalipuram, perfect for photos and soaking in the charm of this ancient coastal town."

"Today, I had the privilege of visiting the iconic Krishna's Butter Ball, and I must say, it was an absolutely mesmerizing experience! This massive granite boulder, precariously perched on a slope, is a testament to the incredible laws of physics.

As I watched, awestruck, I couldn't help but wonder how this massive rock had defied gravity for centuries. The sheer magnitude of the boulder, combined with its seemingly impossible balance, left me speechless.

What struck me most, however, was the diverse crowd of visitors from all over India and the world. People of all ages, cultures, and backgrounds had gathered to marvel at this natural wonder. It was heartwarming to see strangers becoming fast friends, bonding over their shared wonder.

Krishna's Butter Ball is truly a beautiful place that must be experienced. It's a reminder of the awe-inspiring power of nature and the incredible secrets that physics holds. If you ever find yourself in Mahabalipuram, do not miss this incredible attraction!

Rating: 5/5 stars"

Visiting Krishna’s Butterball in Mahabalipuram with my friends felt like stepping into a storybook. The sight of that giant boulder, mysteriously balanced on a slope for centuries, left us completely amazed — how could something so massive just stay there, untouched by time? We climbed nearby rocks, sat beneath the boulder half in awe and half playfully nervous, and took dozens of funny pictures pretending to hold it up. The warm sun, cool breeze, and laughter made the day even more special. Sharing snacks on the grass and stories under its shadow, we realized this wasn’t just sightseeing — it was a beautiful blend of history, nature, and pure fun. A simple rock, yet a memory we’ll treasure forever..

reviews.reviewText:
We, group of 6 friends of over 65 years age went to this place along with our wives for a get-together. Experience was lovely. Starting from welcome drink followed by lunch (includes 4 non-veg dishes) and evening snacks and coffee/tea.
Spacious dining area (with roof) facing the sea. (This place has its own private seashore). Ample space for sitting outside the dining area on the shore with lots of trees.
Enjoyed our stay.
Tariff is reasonable - Rs. 1600.00 plus gst 18%- with one room for refreshing. Rooms are near and clean. Few  rest rooms are also there which are maintained well.
Staff are courteous and helpful. One coordinator is allotted to us. On the whole we had a  fabulous get-together.

Visited this resort quite few times. The resort has renovated the dinning hall near the shore and before it was in the lawn area. They rent this place for destination beach wedding and day out packages. The food is good and also the people at the restaurant are very friendly. The rooms look bit old but they are good in size and was kept well. The swimming pool was nice and the rooms near the pool was good compare to others on the other side. sometimes the parking space gets packed when some program takes place at this venue. Overall a great resort and a prefect get away space close to Chennai.

Had a Joyful meeting with college friends. 30 years have passed. And still strong and well bonded. It was nice location to have such gathering allowing us to share our memories in a calm environment. Pleasant beach side adds a refreshing experience. Totally, it was a wonderful day.

Rating: ★★☆☆☆ (2/5)

Visited the resort for a day outing and overall the experience did not meet our expectations.

Swimming pool access was only for 2 hours, and the water was too hot to enjoy. No fun pool items like balls were provided.

Indoor games were not available, and there were no proper outdoor play areas or pitches.

We were provided with just one room for 16 people. Though the room was clean, it was not spacious or comfortable enough for such a large group.

Only two 500ml water bottles were provided in the room, which is insufficient. Drinking water throughout the day was also not well arranged.

The welcome drink (watermelon juice) was not refreshing or up to the mark.

Vegetarian food was okay, but not as expected, and they served only two non-veg items.

Car parking was okay and well managed.

The only highlight was the private beach area, which gave us some space to enjoy a few outdoor games.

The resort has potential but needs major improvements in hospitality, facilities, and overall guest experience.

We booked this resort through our company for a one-day outing. Unfortunately, the experience was not up to expectations.

- The rooms were uncomfortable and not well-maintained, especially considering the high price.
- While the atmosphere of the place was pleasant, the food was just average.
- We were not informed in advance about the swimming pool rules during our phone discussions.
- Despite the itinerary mentioning various sports activities, no sports equipment was provided.
- There was also no lifeguard present near the beach, which is a serious safety concern.

Overall, the resort seems to be running on its old reputation, and it no longer offers value for money. Personally, I wouldn’t recommend it.

I was with a group of 11 people. Everyone is very happy about the nice stay. The staff and food is amazing, there's a beautiful beach and the rooms are spacious and cozy. It's very clean everywhere. Thank you!

Wonderful location to spend the weekend.  Beach facing suites are the special attraction here. The complementary breakfast is worth it and makes you feel that half the room rent is spent on it. You can watch the sunrise and keep remembering that for a lifetime. The resort management takes special care in seeing that the stay is most comfortable for each and every guest

We had our college reunion. The arrangements were good and they ensure all our rooms were next to each other to make accessibility easier. Tasty food, Courteous staff and nice property made the event more memorable.

sources.snippet: These resorts have exquisite rooms with a private balcony overlooking the sea. You can sit in a rocking chair enjoying the cool breeze and the splendid view of the beach. The restaurants and bars in the resorts offer stunning views of the azure waters of the Bay of Bengal, where you can relish the delicious food and sip on your cocktail while enjoying the fascinating view of the sea.

placeMetadata.description: Upscale resort with an outdoor pool, a spa, & a private beach, plus a 24-hour bar & 2 restaurants.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Experience the ultimate beachside luxury at Chariot Beach Resort Mahabalipuram, nestled amidst the picturesque sandy beaches and clear waters of Tamil Nadu. The resort offers comfortable air-conditioned deluxe rooms with attached washrooms and stunning views of the sea from private balconies. Indulge in relaxation with a spa, outdoor pool, and private beach access. Enjoy delectable dining options with breathtaking views of the Bay of Bengal at the resort's restaurants and bars.
placeMetadata.address: Five Rathas Road, behind Five Rathas Monument, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

reviews.reviewText:
From the moment I arrived at Chariot Beach Resort, I felt a deep sense of peace and luxury. The property is vast, beautifully maintained, and opens right onto a stunning stretch of beach soft sand, clean waves, and pure serenity.

The staff were incredibly warm, helpful, and attentive. Every interaction felt genuine and full of care. Special thanks to the front desk and housekeeping and restaurant  staffs for making everything seamless.

My room was spacious, spotless, and perfectly comfortable, with a lovely view and the sound of the ocean in the background. The pool area is a total highlight ideal for both relaxation and fun. And the food? Outstanding. Every meal at their restaurants was fresh, flavorful, and served with grace. The seafood in particular was a standout.

The resort is perfectly located near all of Mahabalipuram’s major sights like the Shore Temple and Five Rathas—which made exploring effortless. But honestly, just being on the property itself is an experience.

Whether you’re coming to unwind, explore heritage, or just escape into nature, this place delivers. I left feeling recharged, inspired, and already dreaming of my next visit.

Highly, highly recommended.

Chariot Beach Resort, Mahabalipuram (Stay: 18–20 April 2025)
April 2025

We stayed at Chariot Beach Resort for two nights (18–20 April'25) , having booked an Executive Deluxe room with an extra bed. While the property itself is spacious and scenic, the overall experience was disappointing, especially considering the premium price point.

The room was average, and the bathroom appeared more like a makeshift setup—far below expectations. Key amenities were either missing or non-functional: the hair dryer didn’t work initially (a replacement was provided later), the television wasn’t working throughout the stay despite multiple complaints, and there was no hot water. Returning drenched from the beach, both my children (aged 1 and 6) had to bathe in cold water, and the chill even caused discomfort to my elder kid.

Repeated complaints about the TV and hot water went unanswered. The staff seemed unresponsive, and resolution came only after escalation by Chef Karthik—who, despite it being outside his scope, was proactive and supportive. Eventually, we were moved to a cottage at 10 PM on the second night, which felt too little, too late.

One saving grace was the team at the restaurant. Chef Karthik and his superior were genuinely thoughtful, and the GM himself assisted in preparing baby food—something the hotel does not charge for, which was appreciated. The pool was another highlight, with the kids thoroughly enjoying their time there.

Overall, while the property has potential, the lack of basic room checks and poor responsiveness to issues made the experience underwhelming. Hope the management works on service quality to match the property's promise.

Had a pleasant check-in experience with a warm welcome from the front office team. The resort is set on a huge property with rooms located conveniently close to the beach, and the staff were courteous and helpful throughout our stay.

The swimming pool is spacious, with a good number of shower areas and towels available, which added to the comfort.

However, the rooms did not quite match the price point — the AC was quite loud, and the bathrooms were maintained at a basic level. The breakfast buffet spread was limited, with a strong focus on South Indian cuisine and very few continental options.

For a resort of this scale and pricing, there’s definitely room for improvement in the overall standard and upkeep of the rooms.

All over is good. Food is very tasty.
But the adventure game is quite tough and quite dangerous for the people also the tent was very hot and the fan was very less.
Maintenance is really bad and needs improvement. Even in the entrance reception fans are randomly fitted and sofas are placed on one side and fans are fitted in some other places.
Please check and do the needful for the people and visitors

Friendly staff, but overall disappointing.
We visited the resort for a day outing. While the staff were friendly and welcoming, the overall experience was disappointing. The food served was below average in both quality and taste. The property was not well maintained, several areas looked run-down and neglected. For a day trip, we expected a cleaner, more enjoyable environment. Definitely not worth the cost.

The front desk was helpful and pleasant, but there are some issues that need serious attention, the swimming pool is dirty and poorly maintained, slime is on the walls of the pool, dirt at the floor in the bottom , water is not clear, rather full of algae.its like a swamp. I entered the pool and got eye irritation. it's unsafe to have such a pool and a waste of money, an amenity shown prominently to the cost of a guest's ticket.was unable to use it, not fit for swimming . was like a village pond, rather than a class hotel's swimming pool. the toilet flush was not working , we had to call three times , to get it rectified. the hot water wasnt turned on, only after calling it started working. There was a bad rotten stench at the beach, that may be out of their control, some dead rat or something. The other complaints need attention, it did impact our stay and significantly ruined any hopes of calling it a pleasant stay. the room was clean, view was good from the window.the front desk was courteous. but the restaurant denied ala carte for dinner.That was a turnoff. I have pictures of the swimming pool, for a guest paying rs 13k for a night, I feel, my experience needs to be better compensated.I hadn’t yet posted a public review, waited for their response,but no response to email .I did want to meet the operation manager during checkout, but he/she was on leave , not onsite, a ruse ?

Decent stay with scope for improvement.

We got here on a last minute trip , booked it en route in our drive.

It was not cheap at INR 17k for one night.

The room itself needed work - the curtains were falling apart, the phone wasn’t working, the bathroom didn’t have enough place to hang out wet clothes.   There was no hair dryer. It had free water to drink and some snacks , and it didn’t say anywhere that the snacks were paid. We were charged inr 500 for 3 snacks which our guest ate without knowing. A message next to the snacks would have been good.

The property was okay - it has a pool, but some of the tiles were broken, so they offered water shoes. There was an activity room that had decent things to play for kids and adults like table tennis and billiards. We didn’t try the paid activities.

The beach was also good but it was a red day so we couldn’t wade into the water.

Service was good. People were helpful and were responsive in the property.

Breakfast buffet was decent, lots of fresh vegetarian options but I was unhappy to see that some food was open to the air and had flies sitting on it, till I asked to them cover it. Easy to fall sick.

It was alright stay. I was not super impressed, but I’ll give them points for their service.

Well, we stayed here from 18th April to 20th April.
We faced multiple issues listed below:
1. Staff was not trained properly. For spa, they informed that the printed rate is the final bill including tax, but while paying they charged the taxes. When we confronted her, she lies straight way that she told that the printed rate is excluding tax.

2. Swimming pool water was very hard as it was full of chlorine and it was under maintained.

3. We were made to wait for 45 minutes after giving order for lunch.
4. Lack of coordination between staff. Even after waiting for 40 minutes for buggy, we had to walk finally.
5. Water bottle brate was 20, but they charged 123 including tax which is illegal. Anyway, I am going to file a consumer court complaint for it.

6. Most of the staff are new hires. I would advise if anyone is opting their service, you should confirm with the billing desk.

7. So overall the price of stay in the resort did not matched the service they provided.

Thanks

The basic rooms of the place feature a quirky interior, flat-screen TVs, mini-fridges, and a separate bathroom as well. On the other hand, the Villas of the property contain rainfall showers, separate sitting areas, and a calm yet gorgeous terrace.

The accommodations feature quirky interiors, flat-screen TVs, mini-fridges, and separate bathrooms. Villas boast rainfall showers, sitting areas, and serene terraces. reviews.reviewText: Nice place with private beach cottage rooms. The issue was with lizards all over which were taken away by the staff. Rooms and surroundings to be better prepared to avoid such. Other wise rooms were good.
Feel as your own weekend home. The no fuss resort. Simple rooms, good service. Right on the beach property. Good service. If in a small or big group, make you own food menu. Especially Gujarati food.

Because of a positive Conde Nast review, we booked this Hotel for a relaxing 1-week stay in mid May, 2024. When we arrived we were shown to our Oceanfront Room with an indicated in-room temperature of 92 degrees Fahrenheit! A Technician was called and by bedtime the temperature was at 88 degrees -- 7 hours after arrival. During the night they offered us the adjoining Suite -- a larger room that was at 88 degrees as well. By morning our original room was at a balmy 86 degrees. Uninhabitable! Management offered us a room at their sister Hotel -- Silversands Beach. That room was immediately adjacent to an outdoor Restaurant not part of the Hotel. Relaxing? Being handicapped, that mountainous Property was not appropriate at all.  We told Management that we could not endure these conditions and were leaving. After meeting with the Manager, we were offered a $1600 Courtesy Refund against the $8000 we had prepaid. They stressed "NO REFUNDS"! With no choice we left anyway and found a wonderful oceanfront Hotel a mile away to have the "relaxing vacation" we counted on. Management at Silversands was completely unapologetic about the insufficient A/C, and zeroed in only on the 2 options they offered us. In addition, their "highly touted" Infinity Pool was under construction with 7 workers constantly drilling and hammering that went on until 7:30 PM that first and only night. If you are considering this Property do yourself a favor and consider my review. Have I ever lied to you before? Conde Nast -- SHAME ON YOU! Silversands Resort -- SHAME ON YOU! See my Review and Silversands vapid Response on TripAdvisor.

The rooms are good but found leakage in the ceiling (it rained and we saw water dripping inside)😐The toilet/bathrooms could be better maintained (one room was good while the other was stinking). The cost is above par.
Property location is very good. It is managed only by few guys and hence service might not be upto the expectation of a resort.
Swimming pool is very good and well maintained. The food inside is extremely costly and does not have much variety. While, you may think of getting food from outside (not much options though)

Decent place, the property is very nice, staff is helpful as well. Rooms are clean and hygienic, nothing fancy. The view and access to beach is amazing and a very good place. It does offer a very good privacy due to limited rooms on a large property. Connectivity is also very good as it's right there on the main road.

My mother and I spent three days in one of the 'standard villas'. The room was lovely and spacious, with an amazing big hammam-style bathroom and an additional outdoors shower, which was a highlight. The quiet and clean beach is a 2min walk away, and their very simple restaurant right by the beach. The pool also has sea view and gets a lovely breeze. Definitely take advantage of the room service - Velu, one of the staff members, created some really beautiful and impressive towel sculptures for us.
Overall a very enjoyable stay.

Nice place for team outing. The ambience was good, the staff were very courteous. The food taste was excellent.
We took a package of 1400 rupees per head which includes beach and swimming pool access, adventure games setup and for indoor games they had table tennis, foosball, snooker and carrom. You can choose your menu for that day from the listed.
The entrance may not be attractive like other resorts but worth a try...

We stayed here during the 2017 New year eve.  This is a pure vegetarian resort. The rooms were pretty big and spacious with good AC. Bathrooms were clean and well kept. Room service was good. They would help you with any matter related to the room. Food is served to the room on request. Food is okay, nothing fancy.
The beach is a short 100 meter walk from the rooms. They also have a small infinity pool near the beach.
The property has some interesting adventure sports such as artificial wall climbing, obstacle course, Rappelling etc. They also had indoor games such as table tennis and Foosball.
They had a special buffet meal on new years night which was not that great.
This place is good for pure vegetarians who would like to find some quiet and peaceful time.

reviews.reviewText: This place is a gem! It was one of the highlights of my India trip! It is full of charm yet it is simple. Staff is warm and friendly, beach is walkable and their restaurant is great! The walk to Mamallapuram center by the beach is spectacular! Recommended!

Don't waste your money by booking this resort..poor service especially complement breakfast... treated like begging...all people were hunger on money and owner's wife was arguing unnecessarily and treated the customers badly for their fault...cost is too higher for that normal room. Very old style and AC is not proper..had yellow colour old lights.... Spoiled our moods because of that lady even though beach was too good..She don't know how to speak with the customers speaking harsly without listening to the customers words. ... book another good resort and save your money and enjoy...

Had the best experience here. The rooms are quite clean and affordable. The major attractive point is that the sea is hardly 300 mts from the place and you get to enjoy a very private time at the sea. The breakfast which is included in the package was very good. Would recommend this place to anyone with family.

I have been a loyal customer of Meya Beach Resort, staying here more than 5 times in the last 5 years. However, the quality of hospitality has drastically declined over time.
During my recent stay with extended family and kids, we booked 2 rooms for 2 nights . What we received was highly disappointing—2 small Santoor soaps, 3 Clinic Plus shampoo sachets, worn-out towels, and just 2 small water bottles. On the second day, we were informed that the rooms wouldn’t be cleaned, bedsheets and towels wouldn’t be changed, and no additional water bottles would be provided, which are basic necessities for any stay.
I strongly do not recommend this place for anyone planning a family stay. The standards have fallen far below expectations.
Loved the stay! Staff is Lovely and very nice people. Beach is very accessible. Food is amazing. Rooms are clean and spacious. Surrounded by greens. Highly recommended .

This place was superb! Everything from the rooms to the food was good!
The distance between the hotel rooms and the beach was only a two minute walk which makes it very comfortable for families as well...
Meya, Is a great place for families and individuals looking to enjoy that private beach feel. 👍🏻

Had stayed here during an official Bajaj Dominar Ride to Mamallapuram.

As a ride lead, I try to ensure the stays are carefully chosen with my set of parameters since it's a crucial part of the experience. The choice of opting for Meya turned out to be a great option considering they're in close proximity of the town but away from the crowd, and right by the beach.

The property is enticing with a beautiful entrance with good ambiance and foliage, and the staff greeting you with a wide grin & brilliant hospitality. Ms. Kavita was kind enough to ensure the check-in process was smooth with no hassles, and the proprietor, Mr. Bhaskaran, was there to assist for any requirements.

Good seating area outside the rooms, and the rooms themselves are quite spacious with a rustic vibe. However, some maintenance is required in the washroom with leaky taps.

The restaurant - May1,  is by the beach, ~100m away, and serves good food with the Manager, Mr. Ramesh, offering incredible hospitality and kindness in ensuring the customers are well taken care off.

Only qualm is the parking isn't sufficient with cars parked in as well.

Looking forward to the next stay. Would recommend.

It's very near to beach and their restaurant is on the beach. On special request they setup table on beach and that too without charge. Rooms are comfortable and spacious. Property location is super. It's pretty green and quite. Restaurant food can be improved but it's not that bad. Will give 5 * for everything as their hospitality was outstanding. Will definitely gonna visit them soon. To be honest it's under budget and total value for money.

placeMetadata.name: Mahishasura Mardini Cave

sources.snippet: One being Lord Vishnu sleeping on the coils of the serpent king Adisesha. The second being Goddess Durga fighting the demon king Mahishasura. In addition to the prominent carvings, this cave has three shrines.
sources.shortName: Heritage city of the mighty Pallavas, temples & beaches

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Mahishasura Mardini Cave Temple, dating back to the 7th century, is a remarkable example of Indian rock-cut architecture. Situated in Mahabalipuram, it is dedicated to Goddess Durga and features intricate carvings depicting Hindu deities and mythological scenes. The temple is part of a group of monuments and holds UNESCO World Heritage status.
placeMetadata.address: J58R+MP2, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

reviews.reviewText: This cave is sculpted with the battle between the good and evil the fight between Maa Durga and Mahisasur on one side of the wall and on the other side of the wall you will see Lord Vishnu sleeping (Anatasayan). And on the outside wall you can also see the Decent of the Ganga to the Earth.

There’s a simple yet impressive throne carved straight into the rock, sitting at the top of a few steps on the hill. It’s quite large, with enough room for someone to sit and look out over the nearby village and hills. At one end, there’s a carved lion that faces north. It dates back to the Pallava period in the seventh century, and while it carries a local tale linking it to Yuddhishtira from the Mahabharata, it’s believed to be a royal seat carved for a king who would pause and survey the land.

Reaching the throne only takes a short climb. Climbing up, you sense how naturally the craftsmen shaped it right into the rock, using both myth and landscape in their work. When seated, the breeze around you feels freeing, and the view spreads out below in a calming, almost meditative way.

Most visitors spend around thirty minutes here. It’s a quiet spot showing how art, history, and nature blend together. It doesn’t feel like a tourist trap but more like a gentle reminder of how life and power used to connect with these lands and legends.

​The Mahishasuramardini Cave at Mahabalipuram, a UNESCO World Heritage site, stands as a prime example of Pallava dynasty rock-cut architecture.  Dated to the 7th century CE, this cave temple is a testament to the artistic and engineering prowess of the Pallava kings, particularly King Mahendravarman I or his son, Narasimhavarman I. Carved from a single large rock, its simple yet elegant facade features a pillared porch and three cells, or shrines, at the rear. The pillars are slender and fluted, a distinctive feature of early Pallava architecture. The cave's design beautifully integrates a natural rock formation with intricate sculptural work, creating a sacred space that feels both monumental and intimate.

​The cave's interior is renowned for its magnificent bas-relief panels, which are the focal point of the temple's artistic expression. The northern wall features a stunning panel depicting the slumber of Vishnu, known as Anantashayana. In this serene scene, Lord Vishnu is shown reclining on the cosmic serpent Adishesha, surrounded by various divine and human figures. The composition is calm and harmonious, with a sense of cosmic tranquility that contrasts sharply with the dynamic scene on the opposite wall.
​On the southern wall, the cave's namesake, the Mahishasuramardini panel, comes to life with incredible energy and detail. This dynamic sculpture depicts the goddess Durga engaged in a fierce battle with the buffalo-headed demon Mahishasura. Durga is shown in a triumphant pose, mounted on her lion and wielding a bow, while her adversaries are in a state of chaotic defeat. The scene is full of movement, tension, and power, with figures frozen in mid-action. This panel is considered a masterpiece of Indian art, capturing the emotional intensity and drama of the mythological narrative.
​The Mahishasuramardini Cave, while seemingly simple in its architectural form, is a profound cultural and religious artifact. It not only represents a significant phase in the development of rock-cut temples in Southern India but also serves as a powerful medium for storytelling through stone. The contrasting panels of Vishnu's slumber and Durga's battle encapsulate the duality of divine power the tranquil and the fierce. A visit to this cave is a journey back in time, allowing one to stand in awe of a bygone era's faith, artistic vision, and unwavering devotion, forever immortalized in the granite of Mahabalipuram.

This 7th Century rock cut shrine is one of the best works of ancient art in Mamallapuram . The large , full wall panel of the  slaying of the demon Mahisha by the fabulous Devi , is full of dynamism and animated drama . The scene of Madhu Kaitabha retreating from the Sesha sayana Vishnu , is carved on the opposite wall. These two panels are among the best examples of mature Pallava sculpting and have innumerable detailing which are a treat  to the eyes .
The cave , excavated at the base of the rock upon which is the Old Light House , is incomplete and another rock , facing it , shows tge initial markings for cutting another cave .
Mahishasura Mardini Cave tells about the Religious backgrounds of Pallavas and also to show the event to kill Mahishasuran by God Durga in an art form.

This is an example of the Indian rock cut architecture dating back to the 7th century of the Pallava dynasty. This cave temple is a part of the group of monuments and also an UNESCO world heritage site. This is one of the most important caves in Mahabalipuram and dedicated to the goddess Mahishasurmardini, another name of Goddess Durga. There are lot of pictorial inscriptions on the cave walls for the history buffs. Since we visited with one trip organizers, we kind of had to wind up within an HR. Highly recommended for history buffs.
good

Mahishasuramardini Cave Temple
Located at the southern end of Mamallapuram Hill, Mahishasuramardini Cave Temple is noted for its reliefs that have been intricately carved into walls. One of these depicts Lord Vishnu sleeping on top of the coils of the king of serpents, Adisesha, while another relief displays Goddess Durga, atop her lion, fighting with the demon Mahishasura. Apart from these two bas-reliefs, the shrine in the centre of the temple holds an idol of Lord Murugan, seated between Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati. Carved out of rocks, the temple depicts scenes from ancient Hindu epics, Puranas. The cave temple belongs to the 7th century, constructed under the Pallava dynasty (275 CE to 897 CE). The cave is a testimony to the fine craftsmanship of the Vishwakarma sculptors of that time.

placeMetadata.name: MUMU SURF SCHOOL

sources.snippet: To notch it up a bit, if you have sometime in your hand and a ﬁre within to learn something new, then there’s a Surf school called MUMU Surf School about a kilometer from beach, they teach surﬁng and help with little tips & tricks. They have courses that stretch for days and it’s said that the waves and the current at the beach is just about perfect to surf along!
sources.shortName: Mahabalipuram Beach in Tamil Nadu India

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: MUMU Surf School, located about a kilometer from the beach, offers professional surfing lessons and insider tips to help enthusiasts master the sport. The school provides multi-day courses tailored to different skill levels, taking advantage of the ideal waves and currents at the nearby beach. Visitors have praised MUMU for its welcoming atmosphere and highly skilled team, particularly highlighting the expertise of surf coach Magee.
placeMetadata.address: Othavadai St, Fisherman Colony, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

reviews.reviewText: I ended up in Mamallapuram after reading an article in Mint, and I had an amazing experience learning something new: surfing. I never thought I'd try surfing, but there I was. Murali was fantastic, and my instructor Ruben was a lot of fun. He provided clear instructions and corrected me every time I fell 😂. I'll definitely be back soon @mumusurfschool.

Mumu surf school out of all the available ones is the BEST. Im beyond grateful to have my first surfing experience with the best coaches. Murali sir, the manager, was very coordinating and met all the requirements. We were coached under Kishore sir who very calmly and with patience taught us how to surf. We had multiple practice rounds and finally gave our first and final shot at surfing.
I highly recommend Mumu Surf School to anyone who wishes to have the greatest experience surfing, beginner or advance level.

The best you will find in Goa, if you are a beginner, don't know how to swim, no worries just leave it to them and they will ensure they create the safest envoirament and teach you how to surf. Thanks Mumu ❤️💪

It's the best place to learn, kishore was my instructor, he explained everything in a simple  way. I really loved it. I'm planning to visit the place again.

The water is not that deep. So people who can't  swim also can learn.

Iny first session itself I was able to control. This will make you feel alive.

Also the place is not crowded.

, 💝 💝

*Detailed Review*
I drove around 350kms on a bike from Bengaluru to Mahabalipuram following Google Maps to learn surfing from Mumu Surf School.

The road is nice and safe to drive, I was driving with my girlfriend (she also drives). I left at 11 AM in Bengaluru to reach Daphne Hotel ( Mahabalipuram ) by 7:30 PM.

I took 3 day course (everyday 90 minutes) under Kishore (our guide). He is the best instructor. I was able to surf somehow on the first day.

For people working from home, you can take the morning session, and still do your office.

Mahabalipuram is a very good place for surfing. The place hosts many national and international championships. People from other countries come to learn surfing here too. I met a German lady in the same hotel, though she broke her leg while surfing (she was an old lady).

Surfing does not require swimming at this place, but if you know swimming, you will have extra confidence over water.

Mahabalipuram as a place is empty, there are some good resorts, and it has a temple on the beach. Apart from this, I only liked surfing.

This is the nearest place from Bengaluru where you can learn to surf and reach by road.

Extras:-
1. You can rent surf boards and have fun all day.
2. Wifi provided by Hotel did not work. My Airtel 5G worked very good.
3. I went in June, AC room was not required. Shops outside close early, and open late.
4. Try to wear full body swim suits, as you may be lucky and get sting by Jelly fish.

This surf school is amazing, with very experienced coaches. I recently had my 3 days surf classes here in june’25. My coach Kishor was really an amazing guy. He made sure that I keep pushing my boundaries and get all the learning. Other coaches too I saw were quite passionate for surfing and quite encouraging.

I had my first surf lesson with Mumu surf school and I could not be more chuffed! Great vibes, respect and always a go go attitude! Being a solo woman travelling this is a safe place to be you, learn how to surf and have fun. You can even donate your change to feed the stray dogs from the beach. Mumu is the man, looking after humans and doggos ❣️

I had a fantastic experience taking surf lessons from Mumu Surf School at Mahabalipuram. Mumu, Kishore and Mahendran are excellent trainers at sea - very kind, patient, knowledgeable and expert surfers.

Apart from the technical instruction, they seem to really understand how to prepare oneself mentally and emotionally to face the waves and enjoy the experience of surfing which took my lessons to a whole new level.

Thanks so much. I will be back again.😊

Besides, here, you will also be able to find a huge tennis court, a separate indoor gaming room, and a lush green garden.
